The reason I draw these matters to the attention of the House in the context of our debate today on the foreign aid statement is to highlight what Australia can do to assist the region in responding to the emerging threat of such a pandemic. The government has allocated $5 million to cover the raft of efforts directed towards the monitoring of internationally communicable diseases in the region. Avian flu represents a new and more significant challenge on that score. I ask the minister to consider soberly the possibility of Australia taking a regional leadership role in developing a comprehensive regional strategy, on the avian flu threat in particular, which audits all capacities across the region and seeks to fill capacity gaps where they exist. (Time expired)
Debate (on motion by Mr Downer) adjourned.

debateinfo.title: FAMILY AND COMMUNITY SERVICES AND VETERANS' AFFAIRS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (FURTHER 2004 ELECTION COMMITMENTS AND OTHER MEASURES) BILL 2005

subdebate.1.para: Message received from the Senate returning the bill without amendment or request.

talk.start.para: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Brand proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

quote.para: The Government’s failure to manage the economy in a way that secures Australia’s long term prosperity.

subdebate.1.para: I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

talk.start.para: —It is not surprising that a government that has been in office for nine years should have afflicting it a case of terminal arrogance. That really does happen quite frequently, and it is not an unusual fact of life in history in this country. This government, after nine years, is exhibiting all those strands of terminal arrogance that we have seen emerge from time to time. In opposition, sometimes it is annoying to have to sit and listen to that terminal arrogance, but you know that the electorate ultimately deals with it. You have that satisfaction and therefore it worries you less.

speech.para: What worries you more than a case of terminal arrogance in the government is ignorance. The concern that I had with question time today, listening to the Prime Minister’s answers, is how far he is from a serious understanding of the principal capacity constraint now in the economy—one that goes to the skills of the Australian people. It is ideological prejudice which has brought those opposite to where they are; it is not the wealth of the economy that has brought them to this point. The de-skilling of the Australian work force is a product of ideological prejudice and policy failure. That is what has happened here. It is important to understand that and important to understand how far the Prime Minister is from solutions and how far he is from understanding.

For example, one of his defences of himself today was to point out to the deputy leader of the Labor Party that the traineeships in McDonald’s and the like attracted a $1,300 subsidy but that a mechanic’s apprenticeship or a building worker’s apprenticeship attracted a $5,000 subsidy—as though that was a defence. He seems to have absolutely no awareness of the fact that one is a one-year traineeship and the other is a four-year traineeship, and that is why there is a difference between those two in the amounts that we are talking about. He says, ‘There are 38 per cent of people in apprenticeships doing traditional trades but only about 14 per cent of the work force require a traditional trade.’ That is not an answer, because there is a vast array of jobs in the work force that require no training at all.

The question is: is the number of people being trained in traditional trades enough to do the job? That is the question—not the percentage of the total number being offered by the government. Of course, if we take that back 20 years, the proportion was 100 per cent of those that were being offered for training. There was that unawareness on the part of the Prime Minister of what it was that he was dealing with.

As a Western Australian I find it particularly embittering because, day after day, I have to listen to the complaints of Western Australian businesses, particularly in the mining industry. They say that they are shelving project after project because they cannot get the geologists they need, the metallurgists they need, the electricians they need, the mechanics they need—a whole raft of skilled workers, from those in the traditional trades and apprenticeships right through to the missing elements amongst university graduates. They say to me, too, unfortunately, that going overseas is no answer, because they cannot get such people there either.

Having failed to deliver the number of skilled workers that this country needs to deal with these capacity constraints, the Prime Minister’s decision—which he defended here today—is that we are going to import them from overseas. This is when we still have five per cent unemployment in this country and when we have had 270,000 young Australians turned away from TAFE over the course of the last five years. We are going to import people from overseas. The miners tell me that that is no good because the people are not there either. Therefore there are no solutions. The solution was for the government to do its job for the last five years. That was the solution. Then there would have been no capacity constraint. There would be no crisis now in the Western Australian minerals industry if that had occurred.

The Prime Minister chastises the Deputy Leader of the Opposition for being somewhat ambivalent about his technical colleges. We know where those opposite came from. The technical colleges reflect their prejudice against the fact that those who are teachers in TAFEs and who have been deprived of resources by the government are basically unionised and basically operate off collective agreements. So we are going to have another TAFE bureaucracy. We are going to have a Commonwealth TAFE bureaucracy.

We on this side of the House say, ‘If you really want to do that, go ahead and do it. That’s fine. We’ll put the legislation through in the Senate. We are not worried about that. If you want to do that, go ahead and do it.’ You do not have one single property acquired to build one of these technical colleges. You do not have one worker recruited to teach in one of these technical colleges. You do not have one body put in place to run any of these technical colleges. You will not get one apprentice from these technical colleges to work in the Western Australian mining industry until 2010.

We will pass your technical colleges but therein is the making of a deal: will you please give those resources that are needed for our TAFEs and vocational education and reinforce what the states are now doing? The states are shortening apprenticeships—with the collaboration of the union movement—by effectively modularising the courses and putting apprentices through faster and by allowing kids in years 11 and 12 to do the first couple of years of their training. The states have got the unions’ agreement to do these sorts of things. The states are working. The states are producing solutions but are getting no help at all from the Commonwealth. The Commonwealth is giving no help to my home state and that has consequences for that magnificent growth we have enjoyed in Western Australia, for which the West Australian government was vigorously rewarded a week or so ago. Western Australia’s magnificent work is now holding up this country. Without it, and the fact that there are quite good terms of trade at the moment for the exports that come from Western Australia, this country would be in a very difficult position indeed and you are not helping it—you are hurting it.

The policies of the Commonwealth government for the last nine years have hurt Western Australia’s mining production industry by depriving them of the one thing that they absolutely need to be able to work. Your solution is to import workers, to bring people from overseas, having failed to train young Australians. You desire to substitute with that labour those young Australians. The fact that the government has done this—

talk.start.para: (Hon. IR Causley)—I take it the ‘you’ in the Leader of the Opposition’s comment is general?

—Yes, it is general. It is not applied to the minister opposite, who has had his period of failure and has gone. It is ‘you’ generically, meaning the government, Mr Deputy Speaker. The fact that the government has failed and is importing these workers is not going to deal with the problem. We have heard from this government over many years endless boasting about its alleged good budget practices, endless boasting about lower taxes, claims that it has a rigorous approach to spending, a commitment to proper accountable fiscal decision making and a commitment to reform.

speech.para: This government has had the benefit of a long run of growth to support it along the way and it has basked in that sunshine. It has claimed credit for every minute of that sunshine. We do not doubt for a minute that this government has had its time in the sun. There are storm clouds now on the horizon and the government has done precious little to shelter Australia from that storm. Nine long years of coasting on other people’s hard work, nine long years of playing clever politics but consistently failing the basic responsibility of government to prepare Australia for the challenges of the future, nine long years of talking tough but squibbing it on the hard decisions and now it is all starting to come apart. It is starting to come apart and the government knows it.

We saw it this week in the consumer confidence figures that were released yesterday. While the Treasurer has been crowing about record levels of consumer confidence we have seen a 16.6 per cent fall in that index—the largest fall seen in any month of that index’s 31-year history. And we saw it last week in the current account deficit figures. With all the mockery that we were subject to on the current account deficit we now have one which in real terms is worse than at any time since the Korean War or during the balance of payments crisis of the 1980s. Australians just look at that and wonder: ‘How is it that we are doing so well when prices for our minerals and energy exports are soaring and we have a massive trade deficit—the longest run of trade deficits ever? How is it with such good fortune we do not even have enough savings in our economy to fund other Australians buying a family home? How is it that if we have done so well we have $421 billion of foreign debt—more than $20,000 of debt for every man, woman and child in Australia?’

The fact is that the cracks are appearing in this government’s facade of economic responsibility. These broken promises on interest rates and this poor performance in trade have happened against a set of promises from this government that they would not occur. This government were re-elected on the basis that interest rates would not rise. This current account deficit and the fact that interest rates are rising have collapsed consumer confidence over the course of the last week. Every Australian who voted for this government at the last election expected something different. We have had the government up here defending themselves on the interest rate rises, variously arguing that the rises do not matter or are very good, or saying, ‘Please don’t do it again, Reserve Bank. Please take note of the fact that we are going to be fiscally responsible in this budget.’ Signal, signal out there to the Reserve Bank governor—‘We will be good boys and we will not place ourselves in a position where we give you cause to be fearful of the next budget that we do.’ Talk about closing the gate after the horse has bolted—a $66 billion horse. This week the Treasurer said to me that he would rather be one of Elizabeth Taylor’s husbands than be responsible for the deficit that was in place when he assumed office. I do not know whether he could ever be one of Elizabeth Taylor’s husbands, but I can tell you this: at $66 billion he could afford the jewels!

Imagine spending $66 billion and not fixing the capacity constraints that are there for the skilling of the Australian population. They boast that of that $66 billion about 1.7 per cent of it went to skills. Virtually all of that 1.7 per cent went to the nonexistent technical colleges which will produce their first graduate in 2010. They will spend $66 billion and not fix the capacity constraints on infrastructure. They will spend $66 billion and still leave an effective marginal tax rate of 61 cents in the dollar for the average family with a couple of kids going into the work force. There is nothing in those figures that came forward today that the government has been able to punch a hole in as far as that fact is concerned. How does that provide an incentive for people to come into the work force and get themselves skilled, when they lose money at that sort of rate? They will spend $66 billion dollars and not fix that.

That $66 billion dollars did do one thing, however. That $66 billion frightened the life out of the Governor of the Reserve Bank. That is why virtually every economic commentator in this country with any sense of responsibility is going back over your political record. They are discovering that this $66 billion is merely a gargantuan representative of what has become a regular pattern. Every time you go to the polls you wreck the economy. Every time you go to the polls you create a situation where you buy yourself back into power and then limit your capacity to do the things you really need to do—because you are going to have to do that in the budget.

They will spend that $66 billion, but I guarantee that in this budget they will not fix the capacity constraints related to skills, they will not fix the capacity constraints related to our national infrastructure, they will not fix the problems in exports, they will not fix the problems for the mining industry in Western Australia, and they will constrain themselves in order not to have more than another couple of hits in the area of interest rates, in the hope that they will survive—but this country will not profit from it. This country will not experience that next layer of growth that we need, that next layer of productivity, if the hard work that we have done to get that growth, for which the Hawke and Keating governments got no credit, is not carried on by a government that ought to respect that legacy. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I say to the Leader of the Opposition that I am only too happy to respect aspects of the legacy which this government inherited from the former Labor government. Certainly financial deregulation, tariff cuts and the beginnings of some privatisations make up a worthy legacy, and this government has built on it. If this government is prepared to give credit, as it should, to its predecessor then surely members opposite should give credit where it is due to this government.

speech.para: I was extremely surprised today to hear from the Leader of the Opposition—normally an accomplished parliamentary performer; normally a highly intelligent commentator, at the very least, on the Australian scene—one of the flattest and dullest MPI speeches I have heard. It was certainly the flattest and dullest MPI speech that it has been my responsibility to respond to. I can see members opposite scarpering out of the House. They should have left 15 minutes earlier. They should have taken the early plane because there was absolutely nothing in the speech of the Leader of the Opposition that was really worth listening to. Today’s MPI is:

quote.para: The Government’s failure to manage the economy in a way that secures Australia’s long term prosperity.

speech.para: You would think it would contain a serious attack on the entire conduct of the government’s economic management over the last nine years. But instead it boiled down to a lament that Australia currently faces a skills shortage.

Of course we do face a skills shortage. Why do we face a skills shortage? Essentially because we have an economy which has grown steadily for the last nine years. Inevitably, at the end of a decade-long economic boom—an economic boom which I certainly hope continues for another decade—there will be some industries and some businesses that face skills shortages. What was the answer of the Leader of the Opposition to this problem? It is one thing to identify a problem; it is another thing to come up with a credible answer. There was not a single skerrick of an answer in the remarks of the Leader of the Opposition today as to what a Labor government would do to fix this problem. There could not be any suggestion from the Leader of the Opposition because for the last couple of weeks he has gone in and out of this building and in and out of the radio and television studios of this country accusing the government of buying its way into office with a $66 billion spending spree.

We all know what the Leader of the Opposition’s solution to skills shortages would be: spend more. But instead of spending it intelligently by going to the market and saying, ‘Give us good value, effective proposals for greater training,’ the Leader of the Opposition would be there building new TAFE colleges, employing more TAFE teachers in the public sector, and doing it the old statist, socialist way of members opposite—with perhaps one or two intelligent exceptions. I certainly would like to hear from the new member for Watson, who at least has some private sector experience, building on his former union credentials. It is absolutely inevitable that anything that members opposite, including the Leader of the Opposition, put up to address the skills shortage would be more of the old statist ways which have been so consistently pursued by the state training systems and which have helped to get us into the current difficulties.

Members opposite claim that the government has failed to manage the economy in a way that secures Australia’s long-term prosperity. These are not boasts from this government; let me give you some facts. We have unemployment at 5.1 per cent, a rate last seen in the mid-1970s, compared to a peak of almost 11 per cent when—guess who?—the current Leader of the Opposition was the minister for employment. We have standard variable mortgage rates at 7.3 per cent. That is down from 10.5 per cent when we came into power and down from 17 per cent at its worst under the former Labor government.

Inflation has averaged 2.4 per cent since March 1996, compared to an average of 5.2 per cent under the former Labor government and a peak of 11.1 per cent. Real disposable household income has grown by an average 3.3 per cent a year since 1996 compared to just 2.2 per cent a year under the former Labor government. The real net wealth of Australian households has increased at an average annual rate of 8.6 per cent under this government compared to 2.9 per cent in the last seven years of the Labor government. Private business investment has grown by 8.3 per cent a year under this government, and is currently at record highs, compared to just 4.3 per cent a year in the last 8½ years of the Labor government.

What we had today was a long and insubstantial complaint from a Leader of the Opposition who has nothing like the record of solid achievement that this government has to its credit. I am prepared to forgive the Leader of the Opposition for the fact that he was the defence minister who gave us the dud subs, that he was the telecommunications minister who gave us the multibillion dollar waste of the Telstra-Optus cable rollout and that he was the finance minister who gave us the $10 billion black hole in his last budget, a black hole that he was denying until his last gasp before the 1996 election. I am even prepared to forgive him the fact that he was the employment minister who presided over almost 11 per cent unemployment, a postwar Australian record—an abysmal record at that.

But what is very hard to forgive in someone who wants to be a credible alternative Prime Minister is the complete lack of any serious suggestions about what he might do if he ever occupied the Treasury benches. What we have had today, and for most of this week, is a long carp about a 0.25 per cent rise in home loan interest rates. No-one wants to see home loan interest rates rise. Members of the government were just as disappointed as members opposite claim to be about this 0.25 per cent interest rate rise. But it comes ill of the Leader of the Opposition, who was part of a government that presided over 17 per cent mortgage rates, to complain about this without showing us how he has changed and what he has learnt. There is no explanation as to why the Beazley of 2005 is different from the Beazley of the eighties and nineties, who was part of a government that consistently failed to deliver the good economic management that this country needs and deserves.

I do not say that this government is perfect. I do not say that 5.1 per cent unemployment is good enough. I would like it to be lower. But at least this government has policies in place that, if implemented—if the Leader of the Opposition is serious about improving our economic performance, he might actually help us over the next few months in the Senate—would, we believe, take unemployment down further. I wish real wages had increased by more than 12 per cent over the last nine years. I really do. I want Australia to be an ever higher wage economy. I think the good working men and women of Australia deserve even higher wages than those they enjoy now. But they are only going to get that if we have a strategy for higher productivity. There has been nothing from members opposite. I think one of the reasons why the good working men and women of Australia continue to vote in large numbers—indeed, in majority numbers—for this government is that they remember that, compared with the 12 per cent real increases delivered by this government, when the members opposite were in power, not only did they cut real wages but they actually boasted about it. Here was the party that claimed to be the party of the workers cutting the real wages of the workers of Australia and boasting about it!

Not once in the life of this government has any tax rate been increased. We had the Leader of the Opposition and other frontbenchers coming into the parliament today and claiming that somehow the Australian people were suffering from the most heinous tax grab in their history, even though this government has not increased one rate of tax. At different stages, it has reduced all rates of tax and at different stages it has increased every threshold for all rates of tax. In 1999, in 2003 and again in 2004 this government delivered a cumulative $17 billion a year tax cut to the Australian people. We were able to do that because of judicious economic management and judicious spending restraint. Every microeconomic reform was opposed by members opposite. Every spending cut was opposed by members opposite. We were able to deliver the $17 billion a year worth of tax cuts despite the constant opposition of members opposite, and now they have the hide to say it is not enough. Of course we want tax to be lower; of course we want to cut taxes further. But you cannot responsibly cut taxes unless you have the revenue and you have the spending restraint that will justify it.

I challenge members opposite to come up with any serious government spend that they have ever wanted to cut. I challenge members opposite to come up with a single part of the so-called $66 billion worth of spending spree that they are against. What they want now is even more spending, on the old statist socialist training systems of the states, which have been so comparatively ineffective in addressing the skills issues that members opposite are now pointing to.

I have considerable respect for the Leader of the Opposition. No-one would deny that the Leader of the Opposition is a decent human being, a competent parliamentarian and an expert massager of the multitudinous hurts of the current federal parliamentary Labor caucus. He is good at all those things. But people are not looking at the Leader of the Opposition to be what he was in the past; they are looking at the Leader of the Opposition to see whether he can be better than that—to see whether he can rise above the political persona of the last 20 years. In the month or so of his resurrected leadership, there has not been the slightest scintilla of serious evidence that he is a changed man—that the rather timid, consensus-driven comparative failure of an opposition leader from 1996 to 2001 has somehow become the kind of dynamic policy-innovator, who is prepared to take hard decisions that he must be if he is going to be a credible alternative Prime Minister at the next election some time in 2007.

Has he said, for instance, that he is prepared to engage with the government to improve our unfair dismissal laws so that businesses can afford to take on more people? Of course he has not. Has he said that he is prepared to engage with the government to get people off disability support pensions and into the work force? Of course he has not. What he cannot do is attack the fundamental problem that members opposite suffer from—they do not know who they represent and they do not know what they believe. This Leader of the Opposition is incapable of resolving those dilemmas. It was the Leader of the Opposition’s famous father who once said that when he joined the Labor Party it contained the cream of the working class but when he left it contained the dregs of middle-class. Nothing that this reborn Leader of the Opposition has done will change that. That is the real challenge they face. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —We know that the job of the Leader of the House is not always easy. To have to listen to the drivel spoken by this Leader of the House because the Treasurer cannot front up to the dispatch box and explain to this place and to the Australian community why this government spent $66 billion during the election campaign is a disgrace. The fact is that the Treasurer of this country should be here to account for that expenditure. We know this government is not about taking hard decisions; it is about taking easy ones. This government is about taking decisions in its own interest.

speech.para: In a very famous radio interview on 14 May 1986, then Treasurer Paul Keating said:

quote.para: If this government cannot get manufacturing going again and keep moderate wage outcomes and a sensible economic policy, then Australia is basically done for, we end up being a third-rate economy ... Then you have gone. You are a banana republic.

speech.para: We all remember those words. Why did he make such an extraordinary claim? Keating made that claim because he knew that a large current account deficit was a sign of a government not doing its job. He knew that a large current account deficit was a nail in the coffin for any national economy. Over the next decade Australia, under the stewardship of the federal Labor government, experienced a doubling of the volume of exports and a quadrupling of manufactured exports. Indeed, as Tim Colebatch, the economics editor for the Age,remarked recently:

quote.para: Had those trends—

speech.para: those Labor government trends—

quote.para: continued, by now the current account problem would be behind us.

speech.para: That is what a leading economist said very recently. What has happened as a result of the government’s failure to act? By failing to continue the reforms of the Hawke-Keating years, since 1997 the average growth of export volumes has slumped to three per cent every year and manufactured exports to five per cent. What is the Treasurer’s explanation for this policy failure? It is extraordinary. Apparently, the reason manufacturing exports have risen just five per cent in the last three years compared with the 52 per cent growth in Labor’s last three years in office is because of the congestion at the Dalrymple Bay coal loader. That is the reason there is a 40 per cent difference between the growth under Labor and the growth under this government in the last three years. The government cannot be honest with the Australian public and cannot be honest with itself about the problems that we face. No wonder we are not going in the right direction.

I was looking last night at an IMF world economic outlook chart. Compared with OECD countries, in absolute terms Australia’s current account deficit is the fourth-largest in the world. If you actually treated the Eurozone as one entity, it is the third largest. That is in absolute terms. If you look at the current account balance as a percentage of GDP, now in excess of seven per cent of GDP, arguably Australia now has the worst current account deficit in the OECD.

These are the fundamental problems that this government fails to act upon. This Treasurer has failed to act on the problems that were beginning in the mid-eighties, which were acted upon then by the then Treasurer; this Treasurer—this ‘Kmart Keating’—has failed to act upon the problems. The statistics on government spending—Commonwealth own-purpose spending—are very revealing. It is very interesting to see where the spikes in spending have occurred. The first of the three largest spikes since 1982-83 occurred in that year, 1982-83, before the election in March 1983. Who was the Treasurer in 1982? John Howard, and he presided over the largest Commonwealth expenditure as a proportion of GDP. The next two spikes in expenditure were in the 2000-01 financial year and the 2004-05 financial year.

Effectively, what you have seen are three large spikes over 20 years. On each and every occasion, the Prime Minister of this country has been involved—twice as Prime Minister and once as Treasurer. The only difference between the 1982-83 situation and the last two was that he was not so successful in buying the voters off to get into office. But, in terms of irresponsible decisions by government, they were all the same. Once we look at those forms of expenditure by this government and at the current account deficit, we know this government is not about good public policy; it is about buying its way back into office. That is what it has been doing since 1996, so I think it is very important to put down for the record what the government should be focusing upon.

In question time today we heard the Prime Minister talk about the fact that this government has been focusing on skills. That is not true; this government has not focused upon skills. Look at every employer survey in the last five years. When employers were asked what the major problem was, they did not talk about the Australian Industrial Relations Commission or about labour regulations. They said they had problems finding people with proper skills. That is the problem. It has been there for a very long time—it certainly precedes the rushed announcement for the Australian technical colleges proposal—and the government failed to act to respond to the skills shortages when employers were crying out for the government to do something. Then the Prime Minister has the cheek and temerity to come into this place and expect the members of this House to believe that he has been serious about skills shortages. The fact is that he has not been serious. He has failed the community. He has failed those potential workers who cannot find jobs, not necessarily because the jobs are not out there but because they do not have the appropriate skills for the jobs that are actually in demand.

I say to this government that it is about time it focused on the real issues and expended proper expenditure on infrastructure and skills. In the event that the government does that, I think we will see some improvements in the current account deficit and hopefully some improvements in other economic indicators. I think the government has failed entirely in responsibly looking after the economy. Certainly, it is the case that we have had some success in terms of a decline in unemployment levels. I am the first to concede that if there is a decline in unemployment levels it should be acknowledged, and I acknowledge that decline. But many independent commentators have concluded that many of the benefits that have occurred in the last nine years are a direct result of the hard decisions made by Labor administrations. It is one of those ironies in political life, I suppose, that this Prime Minister has been a beneficiary of those decisions.

What the Prime Minister should be doing is taking a leaf out of the book of those administrations and bringing about serious economic reform, but he has no interest in that. First and foremost, this Prime Minister has a self-interest. He wants to stay in the Lodge and in Kirribilli House—and wherever else he stays; he might go for a third house soon. The fact is that he will want to stay for as long as he can. There are a number of points of distinction between the current Treasurer and the Treasurer back in the 1980s. We know that the Prime Minister may have many challenges in this country but I do not think he is going to be challenged by the Treasurer, because the Treasurer of this country has a heart the size of a split pea. He does not make hard economic decisions and he will not make politically hard decisions. I have to say that both of them have failed the Australian people and failed to make the right decisions to deliver the outcomes required for this country. I stand today to say that it is about time this government started focusing on the real issues that have been affecting the people in this country. It is about time the government started focusing on people who need to get jobs. It is about time the government started to focus on the skills required for those people to get into jobs. Instead of blaming everybody else, instead of finding other culprits, this government should make the necessary hard decisions now. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I never thought I would see a C-grade re-run of Back to the Future. It was a very interesting performance from the member for Gorton. Fancy being so desperate that the member had to resort to quoting and harking back to glorifying Paul Keating. He also said that perhaps the current government should take a leaf out of the previous Labor administration’s book. As a member who has a rural electorate, I do remember Paul Keating being quoted as saying that Australia was the ‘arse end of the earth’ and that if you are not in Sydney you are just camping out. I am certainly not going to take a leaf out of Mr Keating’s book, and thank God that this government has not.

speech.para: I was very interested to listen to the member for Brand. I have occasionally observed well-delivered speeches and commendable performances from this member of the opposition. But today, alas, I was dismally disappointed, as it was one of his most vacuous and disappointing contributions to public debate.

The paucity in the quality of members in the opposition is damning in itself and is at the root of all their problems. You can change leaders, you can reshuffle the frontbench, but they have learnt nothing from the last few years in opposition. The bloody factional wars within the Labor Party have only delivered the faceless men and women from the ranks of the trade union movement—not the real workers but Labor Party hacks, just like the previous speaker, the member for Gorton, who was a union official for 15 years before he was elected to this House. And this is the fundamental problem facing the Labor Party. They are incapable of fulfilling their very important role as an opposition because they are incapable of empathising with the values and concerns of mainstream Australia, as they do not even claim to come from their ranks.

talk.start.para: Mr Bowen interjecting—
(Hon. IR Causley)—The member for Prospect might find himself initiated fairly early if he is not careful.

—Ask anyone in the Labor caucus: the word ‘mainstream’ is blasphemy within the Labor caucus. It matters not that the current Labor leader is the member for Brand—or again, at some stage, the member for Hotham or, if the opposition gets really down and out and desperate, the member for Lilley or someone else. Until they purge themselves of the ideological dinosaurs that are keeping that green leather warm, they will resent and mock, sneer at and belittle mainstream Australia and the concerns that many Australian families and individuals have.

speech.para: People’s economic concerns revolve around financial security—making sure that their children can have a job. Australians well remember when youth unemployment rates peaked under Labor at 34.5 per cent. Labor had a $500 million New Work Opportunities program which had a four per cent success rate, costing Australian taxpayers $143,000 for every job created—and there were not very many of those. The government’s Work for the Dole program has given over 370,000 Australians the opportunity to learn real skills, interact with their community and reintegrate within their local environment. It has given them an opportunity to give something back to the society that supports them. Many have gone on to find jobs, and others have attained the confidence to pursue further qualifications.

When the Leader of the Opposition was Minister for Employment, Education and Training, unemployment peaked at 10.9 per cent. This is a figure that sticks in my mind. It will be burnt in my mind for as long as he is in this place. And he has the gall, the arrogance—perhaps, as the member for Gorton is trying to do, he is trying to mimic former Treasurer and former Prime Minister Keating—to come in here and lecture the government on managing the economy. When Labor left office, this nation faced an unemployment rate of 8.3 per cent. Under this government, economic management and the hard decisions of reform have been undertaken. I am pleased to say that in my electorate of Indi the unemployment rate is at 3.7 per cent.

Apprenticeships festered away under the Labor Party. Only 141,000 apprentices and trainees existed in 1995. This government understands the need to provide choice in education and training. Unlike the Labor Party, it does not turn its nose up at those who do not have a university education. Now almost 400,000 apprentices are learning trades and skills to secure their economic future and that of this nation. In my electorate of Indi we have had a fourfold increase in apprentices, and long may they continue. This government has invested record amounts in vocational education and training. During the recent election, it added another $1.06 billion into vocational education and training and apprentices. Satisfaction with the New Apprenticeships centres is at 90.2 per cent for employers and 92.6 per cent amongst new apprentices.

Unemployment has not been as low since 1976, when Abba had the hit single Fernando and the Datsun 280 was released. Further freeing up the industrial relations system is fundamental to maintaining this jobs growth and critical to laying the foundations of economic prosperity and economic security for all Australians. But what have we seen from the Labor Party? They have refused on over 40 occasions to support the government’s reform to unfair dismissal laws. The opposition leader is on record as saying that the Labor Party do not really represent small business, but the small business sector is critical for employing people. It is critical in providing opportunities, not only jobs but training and apprenticeships as well.

This is what we have come to expect, though, from the Labor Party. They are a slave to the spivs who run most trade unions. The Labor Party cannot stand up to the thugs and bullies in the trade union movement. How can they look small business in the face? When they enter this chamber and bleat about economic management, they have no credibility whatsoever. Just like their state colleagues, especially their counterparts from my home state of Victoria, the federal Labor Party is held political hostage by the disgraceful and often criminal behaviour of parts of the union movement. What better example than Craig Johnston, who wilfully engaged in criminal damage but was lauded as a political prisoner by some elements of the Labor Party? The cost of Federation Square, where workers were allowed a 36-hour week, blew out from $100 million to $450 million. In another deal to keep the unions happy, Steve Bracks refused Commonwealth funding of $90 million towards the $425 million redevelopment of the MCG because the conditions attached to the funding were unacceptable to the building union. The unions run the state Labor governments, and the unions still pull the strings in the federal Labor Party. Labor governments do not hold these union thugs accountable for their extortion of the business and government sectors. How can they, when they are beholden to them for campaign funds? How can they, when they are beholden to them for preselection votes?

When this government was first elected, it faced extremely serious economic challenges. It faced a waterfront that was an international embarrassment. When this government was first elected, only an average of 16.9 containers per hour were being unloaded at our five major ports, and the Labor Party and the unions bleated that it was impossible to increase the container rate at these ports. But, under reforms that were at times very difficult but were undertaken by this government, the figure has jumped to 28.2.

The single greatest investment for most Australians is purchasing their own home. Any government activity that jeopardises this investment destroys the very financial security of many Australian families. We all remember the 17 per cent home interest rates and the 21 per cent farm interest rates. Businesses shut down, families had to sell up their homes, jobs were lost, and families were devastated.

The Labor Party also decided when they left government that it was good enough to leave this government with a $96 billion debt. Australians are now paying $550 less per month on the average mortgage, and this government has paid back $73 billion of Labor’s debt. But then again, those were the days when the Labor Treasurer said it was the recession we had to have—the worst recession in 60 years. When the Labor Party talk about securing Australia’s long-term future, this is the record they should tattoo on their foreheads: the devastation caused by that recession.

One day they say the Australian economy is being managed badly; the next they say that positive economic figures are attributable to their past record. It is typical member for Brand fashion: try and walk both sides of the fence. If the figures are good, of course they must be attributable to the previous Labor government. But if they are bad, just blame it on the current government. That is what happens when Labor have no shame about their economic record. Unfortunately, the Labor Party have not changed much. Only four short months ago, the rising star, the member for Chisholm said: ‘In some ways it is the best thing that could happen to the Labor Party if interest rates’— (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Order! The discussion is now concluded.

—On indulgence, I would like to advise members of sitting arrangements for next week. As advised by you, Mr Speaker, the House will be suspended on Tuesday from 6 p.m. until 8 p.m. in order to deliver the address-in-reply to the Governor-General. The House will resume at 8 p.m. and rise at 9.30 p.m. with the adjournment debate commencing at 9 p.m. To accommodate the required speaking time, the House will sit on Monday evening until 11 p.m., with the adjournment debate to commence at 10.30 p.m.
—Order! It being 4.30 p.m., I propose the question:

motion.para: That the House do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: —I am pleased to report tonight on a new innovation from the opposition. In the Thursday afternoon adjournment, we will be conducting the weekly rap—the week that was in federal parliament. It will be inclusive of an awards ceremony, for the edification of members. We are not expecting it to be completely Academy Award style—frocks and tuxedos are not required—but every week we will nominate some of our parliamentarians in the House, or maybe some of the government’s parliamentarians, for an award of the week.

speech.para: I will start with the first ever award of the week ceremony. The winner of ‘the silliest stunt of the week’ has to be the Treasurer—the member for Higgins, Peter Costello. It has been a long time since we have seen anybody dancing around federal parliament, and dancing badly he was. There was the Treasurer, doing a little jig. Of course, what prompted this from the Treasurer was that he was desperate for a distraction. The Treasurer said: ‘Interest rates are up. I think I’ll do a jig.’ ‘Private health insurance premiums are up. It must be macarena time.’ ‘Growth is slowing in the economy. Did someone say Village People?’ ‘There’s a skills and infrastructure crisis. Let’s boogie.’ ‘The OECD has revealed today that there is a tax take against Australians. Well, I’m kicking up my heels because the money’s in my pocket, not in yours.’

Overall, this award is well deserved because the Treasurer, when faced with bad news all round on the economy, thinks it is better if he says, ‘I’ll dance now.’ He tries to distract people and then lets them feel the full pain of what the Howard government is bringing to Australians. The best thing about this photograph, which immortalises the moment, is that John Howard is laughing. The Prime Minister is laughing, and laugh he may, because he knows that with stunts like this the Treasurer will never be Prime Minister.

talk.start.para: —I think the member has made her point with that picture.

—The ‘silliest stunt of the week’ was the first award. The next award is the ‘you’ve got to be joking’ award. This week the ‘you’ve got to be joking award’ goes to the Prime Minister. He has qualified on two grounds. The first is that he tried to suggest that it was Labor running a scare campaign on Monday. The master of all scare campaigns is lecturing Labor on the political efficacy of scare campaigns! A deserved award, the ‘you’ve got to be joking award’, goes to the Prime Minister. But the Prime Minister managed to get the ‘you’ve got to be joking award’ for two performances. The other one was his complete failure to answer the question as to why Australia’s interest rates were higher than 13 other countries. At first he claimed it was growth. Then, faced with the fact that growth in nine of those countries was more than Australia’s, he resorted to year 2000 statistics as if this would answer the point. The ‘you’ve got to be joking award’ of the week is well deserved by the Prime Minister.

speech.para: Then we have the ‘own goal of the week’ award. It goes to the Minister for Health and Ageing, who managed today to need to add to an answer to a dorothy dixer. Wasn’t he expecting it? Good Lord, the man is Leader of the House as well. He wins the ‘own goal of the week’ award. Then we have the ‘I’m as cute as a python award’, which goes to the Minister for Education, Science and Training, none other than Dr Brendan Nelson. On Tuesday he managed to take a question about skills shortages. Half of the answer was in response to his saying rhetorically, ‘I’m also asked about alternative policies.’ Well, he wasn’t! But he managed to damn with faint praise the member for Braddon by saying: ‘I thank the member for Braddon for his question. He is working very hard and sits up very straight and pays attention.’ Dr Nelson wins the ‘I’m as cute as a python’ award. Then we have the ‘all puff, no answers’ award, which goes to the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations. He managed on eight occasions in the past fortnight to take dorothy dixers on industrial relations but, when simply asked whether the Howard government was going to let the minimum wage fall, he could not manage an answer.

Then we have ‘accountability watch’, which will be another feature of these reports. We have three unanswered questions from this fortnight. Three times Howard government ministers walked away and said that they would report back to the House but they did not. Finally, Mr Speaker, I will leave you with the ‘mystery of the week’. If the Howard government spent $66 billion in getting re-elected and John Howard is 66 on his next birthday, does that mean that, if Treasurer Costello is Prime Minister by the next election, they will only spend $51 billion at the next election because that will be his age on his next birthday? (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I engage with residents and small businesses in my local community regularly, and I rise this evening to voice their urgent concerns.

speech.para: Opposition members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —We are not talking about jokes here; we are talking about something very serious. The Wyong Shire community is living in fear as violence and vandalism in The Entrance area escalates to the point of being out of control. More than 100 anxious and angry residents and shopkeepers attended a public meeting in my electorate this week to discuss the need for urgent measures to address the increasing incidence of crime. They are furious that the state member for The Entrance and new Minister for the Central Coast, Grant McBride, is not doing enough to reduce crime in the area, and I must say, so am I.

speech.para: The Entrance flower shop was robbed at gunpoint last year, a nightmare that owner Jennifer Wilde says she will relive for the rest of her life. And it is not the first incident of antisocial behaviour that she has experienced. A naked man being lewd outside her shop window is something she will never forget. A hairdresser, a sewing centre, a bakery, a shoe store, a Centrelink branch and a pie shop—just to name a few—have all been subjected to criminal activity in The Entrance in recent months. In fact, on the eve of the public forum the town suffered three broken windows and a robbery. One broken window was the second attack on my own office in recent months.

A survey of businesses in the area conducted by members of The Entrance Chamber of Commerce revealed that in the last 18 months to two years there have been well over 100 attacks against businesses in The Entrance area, including at least 47 break and enters, 56 broken windows, six armed hold-ups and numerous daytime thefts and underage drinking—and this is just the crime that gets reported. The guest speaker at the meeting, shadow police minister Peter Debnam, pointed out that a huge amount of crime, particularly juvenile crime, does not get reported. Mr Debnam encouraged meeting attendees to report minor crimes to the police assistance line so that government policy makers can make decisions based on accurate statistics.

Despite these exorbitant figures, my state colleague revealed that police numbers in the Tuggerah Lakes command have fallen from 198 in 2003 to 194 at the end of last year. So crime is on the increase in our local area, and the New South Wales Carr Labor government is addressing the issue by employing fewer police officers. This is not good enough. The community want action on this serious crime problem in Wyong shire. They want to feel safe at home, at work and when they are buying their groceries.

I have had meetings with local business owners in recent weeks and phone calls from elderly residents who are fearful that they are going to be the next victims of crime. They are frustrated that nothing is being done. The Town Centre Management Board provides council rangers who operate at various hours between 1 p.m. and 1 a.m., but they are restricted in what they can do. This issue of our local police force being overworked and underresourced was raised at a similar forum that I held last year, as was the need for more police on the beat in The Entrance between the hours of 1 a.m. and 6 a.m., when the bulk of crime seems to be occurring.

This is not about attacking the local police force, who are doing a great job, but about getting the message to the Minister for the Central Coast, Mr Grant McBride, that greater police presence is needed in the town. Yet, while the local community were getting together to voice their concerns, the member for The Entrance thought it was more important that he attend a function at a local country club. The Central Coast community needs and wants a state member of parliament who speaks up for them, not someone who shirks his responsibility and avoids local problems, going so far as to ask residents to call off the public meeting. I am so disappointed by Mr McBride’s lack of response to this important issue and can only hope that, as a result of the meeting and our continued pressure for a resolution to this serious problem, he will demand his government, the New South Wales Carr Labor government, to increase police presence in our area. It is vital that we take a stand now for the future of our local area.

I would like to take this opportunity to sincerely thank The Entrance and District Chamber of Commerce for taking the initiative to organise the forum; Mr Debnam for his involvement; and local MLA, Mike Gallacher, and representatives from The Entrance police for their attendance. At Mr Debnam’s suggestion, the residents and business owners who were in attendance have agreed to form an action committee to lobby the Carr government to do their bit to increase police presence and restore safety and confidence to our community.

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, you will doubtless recall my longstanding campaign to acquire a Medicare licence for an MRI machine for Concord hospital. Tonight I stand proudly in this House to celebrate a great victory for my constituents in the electorate of Lowe and for the people of the Sydney’s inner west.
Fran Bailey interjecting—

—It was like pulling teeth, Minister. On 24 February this year, following a hard fought, three-year campaign on behalf of Concord Repatriation General Hospital, Sydney’s veteran community and the people of the inner west, the very hardworking local state member for Drummoyne, Angela D’Amore and I were delighted to join with the Executive Director of Concord Repatriation General Hospital, Mr Danny O’Connor; the Director of Radiology, Dr Lloyd Ridley; and senior hospital staff and volunteers to welcome, at long last, the announcement that the government would extend Medicare access to the soon to be installed MRI service at Concord hospital.

speech.para: Our campaign for an MRI licence began in early 2002 when the then chief executive officer of the hospital, Mr Matthew Daly; the head of the Department of Radiology, Dr Lloyd Ridley; and the Director (Medical Administration), Dr Margaret Sanger, invited me to a meeting at Concord Hospital, seeking help to obtain a Medicare eligible magnetic resonance imaging machine for the hospital. Following that meeting I took the matter up here in the House—

talk.start.para: Mr McArthur interjecting—

—for the benefit of the member for Corangamite, as he as one of the whips well knows. Since then I have asked numerous questions of the ministers for health, requesting Commonwealth funding for an MRI machine and a Medicare licence for Concord hospital.

speech.para: From that time, federal health ministers have provided a variety of spurious reasons why the licence could not be granted. I also made numerous speeches and tabled 11 petitions in this chamber. As I said back in 2002 and throughout this campaign, Concord hospital is critical to my electorate and tens of thousands of residents of the inner west. Importantly, it also has a proud and distinguished history serving the veteran community and, significantly, it is a teaching hospital of the University of Sydney. The granting of the MRI licence means that not only will patients and residents of the inner west have easy access to this important medical technology but, critically, the hard won Medicare licence will ensure people will not suffer the substantial out-of-pocket costs when they need an MRI scan.

In April 2003 I was delighted to learn that, following the excellent work done by the local state member, Ms Angela D’Amore, the Carr government committed $2.8 million to the cost of installing the MRI machine with an expectation that this commitment would be matched by the Commonwealth in providing the Medicare licence. In February 2004, the federal ALP matched that commitment by guaranteeing that the licence would be granted by a federal Labor government. The shadow minister, the member for Lalor, who spoke in the previous debate, gave a commitment outside the hospital—

talk.start.para: Mr McArthur interjecting—

—for the benefit of the member for Corangamite. Now at long last, and with Medicare eligibility, the 3T MRI machine—the largest and most advanced of its kind—will soon be available for the benefit of all the patients. This is a victory for everyone who worked so hard throughout the campaign and the 10,337 people who signed one of the 11 MRI petitions I have tabled in this House over nearly three years.

speech.para: I take this opportunity to congratulate Mr Danny O’Connor, Dr Lloyd Ridley, and Director of Medical Services, Dr Margaret Sanger. I also want to thank the Chief Radiographer, Mr John Pasqua; Mary Venchiarutti; and all the radiology staff for supporting the campaign. I give special thanks to Mrs Milka Valdivia, who collected thousands of signatures for the MRI petitions—and I am glad the member for Corangamite is taking all this in. I also congratulate Veteran Liaison Services Coordinator, Ms Alice Kang; the distinguished former NSW state president of the RSL, Mr Rusty Priest; and the entire veteran community, who have also been vital to our campaign for the MRI licence. This issue has been a priority for my electorate for nearly three years. That is why Angela D’Amore and the Carr government have delivered the MRI machine to Concord Hospital and why federal Labor promised the MRI licence.

talk.start.para: —Carr Labor delivered nothing.

—You did not give us the machine; Angela D’Amore and the Carr government got the machine. I am delighted that so many people worked so hard together to achieve this tremendous outcome for the people of my electorate of Lowe, the people of Ms D’Amore’s electorate of Drummoyne and indeed the people of Sydney’s inner west. I can tell the member for Corangamite that it was like pulling teeth, as I said at the start of this debate, because this government would not give us the machine or the licence. (Time expired)

—To tonight’s nominations for awards may I add the member for Lalor for her role as best supporting actress in a comedy film, ‘Medicare Gold’. I wish to advise the House of the Commonwealth protection of the landing site of Captain James Cook at Kurnell, the easternmost part of my electorate. This area continues to be under significant threat from sandmining and inappropriate development. Under the NSW Labor government, sandmining operations have continued to expand to a point where parts of the peninsula have been ruined. Anybody flying in an aircraft over the Kurnell Peninsula will see that it has become a series of lakes, as the greedy sandminers continue to rape and pillage the area.

speech.para: As the federal member for the area—and given that the NSW Labor government generally and the local Labor state member Barry Collier particularly have been loath to take any action to save Kurnell—I decided to seek the protection of this area under the Australian government’s Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act by seeking inclusion of the entire peninsula on the National Heritage List. When I learnt of plans by Rocla Quarry Products to seek rights to mine a new area, stripping another 4.5 million tonnes of sand from the fragile neck of the Kurnell Peninsula, I immediately sought emergency Commonwealth protection under section 324F of the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act. This remains the only successful application for such emergency protection.

On 28 February last I was advised by the Commonwealth Department of the Environment and Heritage that the Australian Heritage Council had decided on my original application and subsequent emergency application to protect this unique and beautiful area. Unfortunately, only the areas directly associated with the landing of Captain Cook and the meeting of Indigenous and European cultures were listed for protection. While I am disappointed by this decision not to list the entire peninsula, I do understand the reason for it. Put simply, the framing of the act and the constitutional power of this parliament is extremely limited in terms of planning powers. In the words of Mr Tom Harley, the Chair of the independent Australian Heritage Council:

quote.para: The National Heritage List includes places which help define what it means to be Australian. The Council must therefore set a very high standard when assessing nominations. ... the National Heritage List will be highly selective. This ... does not mean that other areas of the Kurnell Peninsula do not have ... value.

speech.para: Put simply, the Australian Heritage Council cannot, under the act, protect areas that do not have outstanding heritage value to the nation. In this case they cannot protect areas that are removed from Cook’s landing site and have been degraded by the NSW government’s penchant for development and sandmining. The reason I sought National Heritage List protection was to try to protect this area which has been so badly devastated by continual sandmining. I again quote Mr Tom Harley, the Chair of the Australian Heritage Council. He wrote:

quote.para: The NSW Government is responsible for ensuring that places with State or local heritage are protected.

speech.para: Mr Harley continued:

quote.para: Similarly, it is the NSW Government that presides over the sand mining ...

speech.para: They took away the rights from the local council several years ago and took total control themselves. They have talked about putting in a major housing development alongside the dunes of some 500 houses. They allow the sandmining to go on. Mr Collier has tried to pillory me in the local media, as has the NSW minister for planning—the man who approves the landfills, the development, the heavy industry and the sandmining—Craig Knowles. In fact, Mr Knowles, the kingpin of the development at Kurnell, even compared my efforts and the efforts of others in the electorate to save this important and irreplaceable area as being ‘a bit like wetting yourself in a dark suit—it gives you a warm feeling but nobody notices’. That is comes from the minister for planning, so much care does he take.

I say this to the minister, and more so to Barry Collier: you can try to shift the blame for Kurnell all you like. I have said from the outset that the national heritage listing was about all I can constitutionally do from Canberra. It is up to you and your government to stop all the mining. The national heritage listing, had it covered the sand dunes, would have only acted prospectively. It remains you, Mr Collier, who can end all the sandmining once and for all. This has been my statement from the outset. The national heritage list application is not something that can be done just because I, or the Commonwealth government, want this area protected. It is assessed by an independent statutory body and must stand up to scrutiny within the ambit of the act. Because of you and your government, Mr Collier, the area which contains the sandhills is all but destroyed and cannot be construed by the Heritage Council to meet the stringent guidelines of the act. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Tonight I raise an issue of great concern to the people of the Shortland electorate and surrounding areas, particularly the people of Lake Macquarie and the Central Coast. At the same time, I am seeking the support of the House. The issue that I am raising is the shifting of the Aeropelican service that operates out of Belmont in my electorate to Williamtown by the current owner and the proposal to rezone the land as residential in spite of the fact that that zoning is not appropriate. Aeropelican was operated by Ansett at the time of the Ansett collapse and it was one of the few services they operated that actually made a profit. The current owner, International Air Parts Pty Ltd, purchased Aeropelican from the administrator. Aeropelican first came into operation in 1967. It was the brainchild of Keith Hilder, who realised his dream when he established a commuter service between Belmont and Sydney. Since the new owner has taken over, he has, I believe, systematically run down the service. He has sold off two of the planes. He has reduced the service from 13 to six flights a day and he is in the process—if he has not already—of selling the two remaining twin otters and the service is due to cease operating from Belmont on 1 April.

speech.para: I am so concerned about this that I am placing a motion on the Notice Paper for next week. This motion will emphasise the vital importance of the Aeropelican air service to the people of the area and, at the same time, express my concern and the concern of the people in the area at the owner’s decision to cease operation out of Belmont. I will be pointing out that there is no other commercial air service operating out of Lake Macquarie or the Central Coast of New South Wales—and what a vital service it is for the people of that area. I will be emphasising that this will increase the traffic on the F3 between Newcastle and Sydney, and I will also highlight the fact that there will be staff losses. Whilst the current owner of IAP says that all the staff will be moved to Williamtown, barring two or three who do not want to go, I contradict this as all the ground staff at Belmont will lose their jobs. In addition, some other employees will not have the same number of hours available to work, and one employee who cannot drive will be forced to give up her job.

To give you an idea of the level of support in my community for maintaining this air service, I will read briefly from a fax which I received from a constituent. This is one of many approaches I have received in my office. It says:

quote.para: Both my partner and I use this service regularly and will now be forced to travel to Williamtown (45 minutes) or travel directly to Sydney. This is a major service for the people who live between the Central coast and Newcastle.

speech.para: It goes on to point out that it is an area where there is a growing population, that it is on the eastern side of Lake Macquarie and that there is absolutely no doubt that it is a vital infrastructure for the area.

The owner has stated that moves by the federal government in relation to security and the upgrades that he will be required to undertake are the reason for him having to transfer the service. I have put some questions on the Notice Paper to the Minister for Transport and Regional Services about this and I have also written to him about this. I suspect that the minister will advise me that there are funds available to assist with it. I am so concerned about this that I am launching a petition to all levels of government asking for their support. On Sunday 20 March at 10 o’clock, at a venue to be advised, I will be holding a public meeting within the electorate, and people will be able to come along, pledge their support and work with me to ensure that we maintain this vital service. We hear in this place all the time about how important it is to have viable transport infrastructure and transport services like Aeropelican, a service which has the support of the community and which, in most circumstances, travels with near to capacity, or capacity, loads. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I have risen in this chamber on many occasions to put on record my concerns regarding the Tugun bypass, the most important piece of infrastructure that is under planning for the southern Gold Coast—a piece of infrastructure that has been discussed and debated for close on 20 years. In fact, it has been discussed and debated to death, and residents of the Gold Coast now just want to see this road built.

speech.para: The proposed bypass has been the subject of numerous public meetings and intense media scrutiny for many years. In fact, at one stage a proposed route for the bypass by the Beattie state government included the resumption of 14 residential homes and a major highway running along the fence line of many other homes—in other words, the road was going to destroy the amenity of southern Gold Coast residents. After months of negotiation—and I mean months—and a state election, a final route was decided on by the Queensland state government and agreed to by the New South Wales government and the Commonwealth. It was a route called the C4, to the west of the Gold Coast Airport, which would not impact on the homes of the residents living in Adina Avenue, parallel to the airport.

We did not reach this decision without a lot of finger pointing and political grandstanding. To this day, the New South Wales government have not committed one cent to the construction of the Tugun bypass. The road is being funded with a Commonwealth contribution of $120 million, a huge commitment by the Commonwealth for a road that is essentially not our responsibility. But the federal Minister for Transport and Regional Services, the Hon. John Anderson, recognised the importance of this road to the southern Gold Coast and put the dollars on the table. The Queensland government also committed to the project—$240 million—but no assistance in funding from the New South Wales government has been received, even though more than half the road is in New South Wales.

But I digress. Once we had locked down the route and locked down the funding for the route, you would have thought we could have moved forward with the planning and the environmental impact study, but we now have more problems. The project is moving forward. The planning process has continued and that planning process is on schedule, but we now have the Gold Coast and Hinterland Environment Council, Gecko, demanding that the New South Wales government stop the building of the bypass by the Queensland government. Gecko have cited environmental concerns for stopping the bypass.

I want to assure the House and the people of the southern Gold Coast that the Tugun bypass will be subject to rigorous environmental and planning approvals by state and federal authorities. The EIS process will examine all of the social, environmental and economic impacts of the planned bypass. An environmental impact statement, or EIS, a species impact statement, or SIS, and a draft major development plan have all been released for public comment. That consultation period began on 13 December last year and will close on 14 March. The process assesses potential impacts, proposes ways to manage them, discusses the likely benefits and establishes a basis for future monitoring when the project proceeds.

The EIS is made up of a series of documents including a number of detailed technical papers which include papers on flora and fauna, traffic and transport, noise and vibration, engineering design, urban design and visual impact, and air, soil and water assessments. There are also papers on the animal species found in the study area, the potential impacts and the measures to mitigate and monitor them. The EIS process is thorough, detailed and gives all those interested the opportunity to voice their concerns or, indeed, their support for the bypass. It is my understanding that Gecko will make a submission to the EIS process. This is the responsible procedure. In that way their concerns can and will be addressed. I refute their claims that the ‘community has been brainwashed into believing that the C4 route was the only viable route and that the problems with this route have been deliberately underestimated year after year’.

The Tugun bypass has been done to death. It is my belief that the road can be built and the environmental issues can be addressed. I do not often pat the Queensland state government on the back but, on this occasion, I believe they have put a lot of thought and planning into the route. I have continued to speak with their planning authorities on a regular basis and raised issues with them myself. The authorities have been nothing short of cooperative.

talk.start.para: —Order! It being 5.00 p.m., the debate is interrupted.
to move:

item.para: notes the vital importance of the Aeropelican air service which operates out of Belmont in Lake Macquarie between Belmont and Sydney and is appalled at the owner’s decision to cease operation out of Belmont;
notes that there is no other commercial air service operating out of either Lake Macquarie or the Central Coast of New South Wales;
recognises that Aeropelican is vital regional infrastructure which provides essential public transport;

notes that air travel from Williamtown is not a viable option for people living in Lake Macquarie and on the Central Coast of New South Wales when they travel to Sydney, and that the closure of Aeropelican will increase the traffic on the F3 Freeway between Lake Macquarie and Sydney; and
notes the transfer of Aeropelican’s air service to Williamtown will result in staff losing their jobs. (Notice given 10 March 2005.)

business.start.para: The DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. IR Causley) took the chair at 9.40 a.m.

talk.start.para: —Today I would like to draw the attention of the House to the recently passed 100th anniversary of the first Rotary club meeting. The first Rotary club was formed on 23 February 1905 by Paul Harris in Chicago, America. Paul was a lawyer who wanted to recapture the sense of community that he felt in small towns during his youth. The name Rotary came from the club’s initial practice of rotating the meeting venues between members’ offices. Rotary was originally formed as a network that could be used to further the professional and social interests of its members, but as the organisation grew so did its mission. Members began using their talents and resources to benefit communities in need. Seventeen years after the first meeting, Rotary clubs existed on six continents and the organisation adopted the name Rotary International. Since then the organisation has continued to grow and on 23 February this year more than 1.2 million members of 31,000 regional Rotary clubs in 166 countries celebrated the organisation’s 100th birthday.

speech.para: Rotary was introduced to Australia in 1921 by two Canadians—James Davidson from Calgary and Lieutenant-Colonel Layton Ralston from Halifax. They originally arrived in Sydney but found the city to be closed; businesses had shut down for Easter and the royal show—or so the story goes. They headed down to Melbourne where the first Australian Rotary club was formed. It has been my honour and great pleasure to be associated with the Rotary movement here in Canberra and I would like to take this opportunity to pay homage to their good works. In the weeks following the Boxing Day tsunami, Canberra Rotarians raised funds that were donated to the Red Cross, World Vision and Care Australia. I understand that the Canberra Rotary Club contributed to the funds needed by Canberra resident Andrew Elston to attend the Ride to Cure Diabetes event in the Barossa Valley in January this year.

I recently had the pleasure of attending a meeting of the Canberra South Rotary Club, which was celebrating the organisation’s 100th anniversary in its own local way. It was there that I met Stephanie Medhurst and Tove Gullikson, two exchange students from America and Sweden studying here through the Rotary exchange program. The Rotary international exchange program is renowned and is a program that all members here would be familiar with. These are just some of the causes that the local chapter supports. I would speak at greater length on this if time allowed me as it is very worth while noting the work of Rotary. Canberra Rotary clubs base their activities around the same principle motto—service above self—that was adopted in the early days of the organisation. Based on that key principle, the good works of Canberra Rotarians look set to continue well into the future and I commend all of them on the occasion of their centenary—something I am sure all members join with me in doing.

talk.start.para: —Recently I had the pleasure of switching on the traffic lights for a new major piece of road infrastructure at the port city of Gladstone. The $15 million port access road provides a direct link between an existing main arterial road and the port central precinct, and will remove about 500 vehicles per day from the CBD. Many of these vehicles are heavy industrial trucks—B-doubles and the like—which cart petroleum and other hazardous products. Most members would know that the port of Gladstone is Queensland’s largest multicommodity port. It generates 34 per cent of the state’s exports by volume, and that will increase further in line with greater throughput at the port. Removing port related vehicles from the CBD area will not only help Gladstone’s industrial expansion and the associated increase in port traffic but also improve public safety and free up the delightful tourism precinct of Flinders Parade. Along with that, many Gladstone families depend on heavy industry for their employment, so the road will help pave the way, indirectly, for more local jobs. The Australian government contributed $7½ million to the project under the Roads of National Importance program—an exemplary form of funding—and this was matched by the Gladstone Port Authority’s $4½ million, the Calliope Shire Council’s $1½ million and the Queensland department of state development’s $1½ million.

speech.para: This was one of the most significant road projects in Gladstone for many years. It involved relocating a railway line to pass under the southern span of an existing bridge, the construction of a road underneath the main street, Goondoon Street, and a new bridge and the creation of an intersection with an existing road. The road would not have been possible without the Roads of National Importance funding, and it is a prime example of what strategic funding can achieve for many towns. I have been working on the port access road since the mid-1990s, hand in hand with the Calliope and Gladstone councils, the Central Queensland Port Authority and Gladstone Area Promotion and Development Ltd. It is gratifying to know that, with the opening coming up in a few weeks time, we are on the cusp of the full completion of this important project. This also comes as part of a wider vision for Gladstone, with its rapid expansion with the opening of Comalco and the possibility of Aldoga opening there. There is a great need for arterial roads and I have been very active in seeing that these are put in place. We have had the Deputy Prime Minister there and we are having another road, known as the Callemondah overpass, completed.
